title: Don't Apologize for Fighting Crime, Mayor Bloomberg
summary: He should be proud, not ashamed, of how he and the NYPD used stop, question and frisk.. Michael Bloomberg has gone from being the nation's top advocate of the police tactic known as "stop and frisk" to abjectly apologizing for its use during his three terms as mayor of New York. Now that he's running for president, his record is being scrutinized and, in some cases, twisted. It's important to understand what stop and frisk is-and what it isn't.

title: Pipeline Foes Try to Shut Canada Down
summary: And Prime Minister Trudeau answers with weakness.. Toronto

title: Defense Department's Top Policy Official Leaving Pentagon
summary: John Rood was removed at the request of the White House; it was unclear whether his role in the Ukraine controversy played a part. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Wednesday that John Rood, who as the Pentagon's undersecretary of defense for policy was one of the top officials in the department, is leaving his post.

title: Without an Independent Watchdog, Who Will Audit the Auditors?
summary: Congress should refuse Trump's request to abolish the oversight board Sarbanes-Oxley created.. The Trump administration is calling for the Securities and Exchange Commission to absorb the independent Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. The president's budget proposal says this would reduce duplication of function and regulatory ambiguity.

title: Petrobras Fourth-Quarter Net Income Almost Quadrupled
summary: Brazilian oil giant cites higher output, lower costs. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian oil giant Petróleo Brasileiro SA, or Petrobras, said Wednesday that profit in the fourth quarter rose as new platforms in the company's rich offshore fields boosted output and cut production costs.

title: Notable & Quotable: Michael Milken
summary: 'It explains a lot if prosecutors think hostile takeovers are crimes.'. Gordon Crovitz on Michael Milken, whom President Trump pardoned Tuesday, in the Journal, May 2, 1990:

title: Ken Griffin Adds Calvin Klein's Hamptons Compound to Collection of Luxury Homes
summary: The billionaire hedge funder is buying the fashion designer's oceanfront mansion in Southampton in an off-market deal. Billionaire Ken Griffin is adding a Hamptons house to his growing portfolio of trophy real estate, this time buying the oceanfront property of fashion designer Calvin Klein, according to sources familiar with the transaction.

title: Bloomberg Bankrolls a Social-Media Army to Push Message
summary: Campaign is hiring workers for $2,500 a month to promote candidate to all their contacts. Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign is hiring hundreds of workers in California to post regularly on their personal social-media accounts in support of the candidate and send text messages to their friends about him.

title: Patients Without Coronavirus Struggle to Get Urgent Care in China
summary: Securing treatment, drugs proves difficult amid roadblocks, hospitals suspending regular services. China has poured doctors, drugs and other resources into Hubei province to battle the coronavirus outbreak at its source, but people with other conditions are struggling to get the urgent medical attention they need.

title: Lamont Gives Up on Tolls in Connecticut
summary: State's governor says he is done waiting for fellow Democrats to act. Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont said he is ready to move on after lawmakers dropped plans to vote on legislation that would add highway tolls for commercial trucks to pay for transportation improvements.

title: More Investment Funds Reduce Ties With Sacklers
summary: Sunriver, DeepCurrents unwind relationships with Sacklers. Two hedge funds are reducing their ties to the embattled Sackler family that owns OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP.

title: Man Shot in Face By ICE Agent Sues
summary: An ICE agent fired a bullet directly at Erick Diaz Cruz's face, a lawsuit alleges. An unarmed 26-year-old man who was shot in the face in Brooklyn by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement earlier this month is suing an unnamed ICE officer over the incident, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday.

title: Federal Reserve Needs Several Judy Sheltons
summary: Economists like Ms. Shelton at least understand the need for market forces in the provision of money even if they tolerate too much state interference. It is no surprise that statists of all stripes oppose her; it is heartening that the president has nominated her.. I am disappointed that your editorial "The War on Judy Shelton" (Feb. 13) doesn't deal with the fundamental question at issue. The federal government is no better able to determine the correct quantity of money or rate of interest than it is to determine the price and production level of computer chips, steel or potatoes. A central bank means central planning, and every economic argument against the state planning apparat of the Soviet Union applies with equal force against central banks. A gold standard isn't quite a free market in money, but it does put the provision of the monetary base in the hands of the free market.

title: Stakeholder Capitalism's Left-Wing Agenda
summary: In reality, stakeholder capitalism is nothing more than an extension of liberal-progressive activism. The only political or social positions these corporate leaders are permitted to take align precisely with progressive values.. Vivek Ramaswamy errs in his basic premise ("The 'Stakeholders' vs. the People," op-ed, Feb. 13). He presumes stakeholder capitalism empowers capitalist leaders to "play a larger role in defining and implementing the country's political and social values."

title: Trump Is Committed but Are the Europeans?
summary: Europe isn't truly committed to NATO, at least not in a financial way.. Regarding Elisabeth Braw's "Trump's America Is Committed to Europe" (op-ed, Feb. 11): Europe isn't truly committed to NATO, at least not in a financial way. The 1% of GDP Europeans claim to contribute is a contrivance of some military but mostly internal security spending-never having met the treaty's required 2% of GDP for true military spending. Since its 1949 establishment, the U.S. has paid for about two-thirds of total NATO costs and expenditures. (Put compound interest on that debt and see who owes what to whom.) The U.S. supplies most of the manpower, logistics, materiel, etc., and the U.S. pays all the costs of shipping it to Europe. In addition, the U.S. pays local taxes and rent for some facilities. In times of NATO maneuvers, the ensuing local disruptions are usually greeted by Europeans with a resigned, "It's those Americans again."

title: Is China More Threatened By the Virus or Criticism?
summary: Holman Jenkins illustrates how Chinese Communists, so-called "materialists," are actually idealists and spiritualists obsessed with controlling thought and information rather than focusing on real, material threats.. Holman Jenkins's "Coronavirus Needs a Free Press" (Business World, Feb. 12) illustrates how Chinese Communists, so-called "materialists," are actually idealists and spiritualists obsessed with controlling thought and information rather than focusing on real, material threats.

title: Tale of Two Cities: Chicago, New York, and War Zones
summary: It seems authorities in New York are targets of criticism for preventing war-zone conditions in certain districts.. Regarding your editorial "Michael Bloomberg's 'Racism'" (Feb. 12) on former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg and the stop, question and frisk policy: It seems authorities in New York are targets of criticism for preventing war-zone conditions in certain districts, while authorities in Chicago are condemned for allowing it.

title: Why One of the World's Largest Tobacco Companies Is Struggling
summary: Pyxus International, with almost $1 billion in near-term debt, is facing a cash crunch. Efforts to move into vaping and cannabis have hit roadblocks.. Pyxus International Inc., one of the world's largest suppliers of tobacco, is facing mounting financial pressure from a decline in its core business and setbacks in its efforts to diversify into cannabis and vaping fluids.

title: IRS Offers Tax-Break Clarity to Accelerate Carbon-Capture Projects
summary: New rules define when companies can start qualifying for expanded tax credit. The Internal Revenue Service provided some clarity Wednesday for companies seeking to use a tax credit for capturing and storing carbon dioxide, taking a first step toward accelerating slow-moving projects, with more detailed rules to come.

title: Homelessness Dominates California Governor's Address
summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom proposes new policies, calls growing number of unhoused people 'a disgrace'. California Gov. Gavin Newsom introduced several proposals Wednesday to address homelessness as he dedicated his annual State of the State address to what he called the state's "most pernicious crisis."

title: Stocks Gain as China Pledges to Support Businesses
summary: Indexes end at or near all-time highs despite disruption caused by coronavirus outbreak; oil prices rise. U.S. stocks rose Wednesday after China launched fresh measures to support local businesses that are struggling because of the coronavirus outbreak.

title: China Expels Three Wall Street Journal Reporters
summary: China's Foreign Ministry says move was punishment for a recent opinion piece published by the Journal. China revoked the press credentials of three Wall Street Journal reporters based in Beijing, the first time the Chinese government has expelled multiple journalists simultaneously from one international news organization since the country began re-engaging with the world in the post-Mao era.

title: First Catholic Diocese in Pennsylvania Declares Bankruptcy
summary: Filing from Harrisburg diocese comes amid mounting liabilities from alleged sexual abuse by clergy. The Catholic Diocese of Harrisburg filed for bankruptcy Wednesday, making it the first in Pennsylvania to seek chapter 11 protection after the state attorney general released a grand-jury report detailing decades of clergy sexual abuse of children.

title: U.S. House Subcommittee Scrutinizes Accounting Rule Maker
summary: Rep. Sherman looks to make accounting rules a focus of the Congressional subcommittee despite legislative obstacles. The new chairman of a House of Representatives subcommittee on capital markets is targeting U.S. accounting rules in a move to increase oversight of a U.S. accounting rule maker, despite a potential battle to enact legislation or alter its powers.

title: Federal Judge Slams PG&E's Efforts to Prevent Wildfires
summary: The judge is considering tying PG&E's executive bonus program entirely to safety goals. A federal judge on Wednesday lambasted PG&E Corp. for falling behind on efforts to trim trees near power lines, which are designed to reduce the risk that its equipment will spark more California wildfires.

title: Energy Companies Face Looming Debt Burden
summary: Explorers and producers have more than $85 billion of debt maturing over the next four years. U.S. oil-and-gas companies need cash, but it won't come at a cheap price.

title: Gold Miners Surge as Haven Rally Continues
summary: Gold prices trade at highest level in almost seven years, pushing up shares of miners. Shares of gold miners extended a recent advance Wednesday, continuing a booming rally that began last summer as investors flocked to the haven metal.

title: Target Faces Labor Organizing Effort at New Jersey Warehouse
summary: Unionization bid comes as Target, other companies move logistics operations closer to urban population centers. A labor clash is brewing at a Target Corp. warehouse in New Jersey where the retailer is testing a new approach to distribution.

title: 'Miss Anthropocene' by Grimes Review: Building a World of Doom and Gloom
summary: The star's much-anticipated fifth album is a deeply rewarding record with a dark edge.. To write science fiction or design immersive videogames, you need to build a world, to construct a place with its own logic, physics and history. Grimes, the Canadian artist born Claire Boucher, assembles records using such a holistic framework. Almost a year ago, she introduced her fifth full-length release, "Miss Anthropocene" (4AD), calling it "a concept album about the anthropomorphic Goddess of climate change." It's finally out Friday, and while the world-building is aesthetically coherent-from the black cover to the grim titles and gloomy arrangements-it's more personal than the initial description indicated.

title: Companies Give Workers Time to Vote
summary: Target and JPMorgan are among firms joining drive to get employees to polls. Hundreds of U.S. companies plan to give employees time off to vote in this year's presidential election as part of a business-led push to lift the nation's traditionally low voter turnout.

title: France Deepens Probe of Ghosn
summary: Spending when he was Renault CEO is under investigation by French prosecutors. PARIS-French authorities are deepening their investigation of spending during Carlos Ghosn's tenure as chief executive of Renault SA, including on a lavish black-tie event he hosted on the grounds of Versailles and millions of dollars in payments to an auto dealer in Oman.

title: Mini Mike or Iron Mike?
summary: Bloomberg can do a public service tonight in Las Vegas.. The consensus of television pundits seems to be that former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who left office more than six years ago, was never a great debater and has been out of the game too long to deliver a winning performance tonight in Las Vegas. This column is guessing that Mr. Bloomberg will be a formidable competitor in his debut on the Democratic presidential debate stage. Win or lose, he will do a great public service if he can help talk one of America's two great political parties down from the Marxist ledge.

title: New York City to Extend Protected Bike Lanes
summary: The plan, which begins with a portion of Sixth Avenue in Midtown, comes after 28 cyclist deaths in 2019. Cyclists will soon be able to ride more safely through Midtown Manhattan as the city extends Sixth Avenue's protected bike lane from Herald Square to Central Park.

title: Etsy Accelerates AI Experimentation Thanks to Cloud
summary: Data analysis, machine learning help company figure out how to nudge browsing customers into buying items. title: Oil Prices Rise After U.S. Sanctions Rosneft Unit
summary: The move could reduce the amount of oil flowing to India and China. Oil prices climbed Wednesday as investors weighed the U.S. sanctions imposed on a subsidiary of Russian-oil giant Rosneft.

title: Three New York Galleries to Sell Financier's Art Collection
summary: Picassos, a Rothko and other works owned by the late Don Marron won't be auctioned but sold privately by a trio of rival galleries. In a rare upset, the world's chief auction houses just lost their bids to sell off one of the most sought-after estates of the season, billionaire collector Don Marron's $450 million art collection. Instead, a trio of top New York galleries have won the coveted assignment-the latest sign that skittish sellers are shunning the auction spotlight amid a shaky art market.

summary: Ruling says lawmakers 'may not erect a wealth barrier' after voters approved restoring 1.4 million people to rolls; state signals it will appeal. summary: Rob Manfred said the MLBPA would only cooperate with the sign-stealing investigation if players received immunity. The union's executive director disputes Manfred's explanation.. title: The Market's Real Worry Is Lack of Worry
summary: Despite recent wobbles on the back of the coronavirus, there are signs of complacency in the equity market. The stock market's coronavirus wobbles may be overdone given the robustness of the U.S. economy, so it is tempting to say that "the only thing to fear is fear itself." What should be concerning, though, is that there is little of it.

title: China Turns to Apps to Control Movements During Outbreak
summary: Tech giants such as Alibaba and Tencent tapped to develop color-coded systems to classify people based on their health conditions and travel history. China's technology titans are deploying health-rating systems to help authorities track the movement of millions of Chinese who are preparing to resume work at factories and other businesses, adding a new and controversial tool in the country's battle to contain the fast-spreading coronavirus outbreak.

title: Boeing Finds Debris in Undelivered MAX Jets
summary: Company conducts inspections for when the grounded aircraft is allowed to return to service. Boeing Co. said Tuesday that it had found debris in the fuel tanks of undelivered 737 MAX jetliners, the latest setback in the plane maker's efforts to address quality-control problems.

title: Trump Supports Sales of High-Tech Products to China, in Blow to Hawks
summary: GE to get export license for jet engines; president's comments come amid debate over protecting U.S. technology. WASHINGTON-A broad push by Trump administration hard-liners to stem the flow of high-tech exports to China-even if doing so means limiting the market access of major U.S. companies-hit a hurdle Tuesday: President Trump himself.

title: Charges Unsealed Against Executives Who Allegedly Paid Bribes in Indonesia
summary: Two former executives of France's Alstom SA and a former executive of Japan's Marubeni Corp. were charged with conspiracy to violate the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. U.S. prosecutors have unsealed charges against three former executives they said were involved in a bribery scheme to win a power project in Indonesia that ended a more than a decade ago.

title: The Strategy Behind the Boy Scouts Bankruptcy
summary: Organization seeks to halt hundreds of child sexual-abuse lawsuits going back decades and protect local scouting councils. In making its historic bankruptcy filing, the Boy Scouts of America halted hundreds of lawsuits over accusations of childhood sexual abuse and sought to protect its local scouting councils from facing those claims.

title: Judge Declines to Delay Roger Stone's Sentencing
summary: Move comes amid tumultuous developments in case of longtime Trump adviser, including withdrawal of four prosecutors. WASHINGTON-A federal judge declined to delay Roger Stone's sentencing, set for Thursday, amid tumultuous developments in the case of the longtime informal adviser to President Trump, including his last-minute request for a new trial.

title: Can the Center Hold?
summary: Students discuss the fate of political centrism in America.. Editor's note: This Future View is about the future of centrism in U.S. politics. For next week we'll ask, "What can all of Mike Bloomberg's billions buy in his run for the Democratic nomination for president? What can't they buy?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Feb. 25. The best responses will be published that night.

title: The Michael Milken Pardon
summary: Trump's act of clemency recalls an era rife with the politics of envy.. President Trump issued several controversial pardons and grants of clemency on Tuesday, but the most welcome was the pardon to legendary financier Michael Milken. The presidential action recognizes that the Milken prosecution of the late 1980s-early 1990s was an example of prosecutorial excess in an era like our own when political gales were raging about "the greed decade."

title: Virginia's Gun-Control Defeat
summary: Democrats abandon a ban on some rifles and magazines.. Democrats took over both houses of the Virginia Legislature in November thanks in large part to voter support for gun control after mass shootings. Or so they claimed. But if they believe that, they now have some explaining to do after Gov. Ralph Northam's restrictive gun-control proposal was shelved Monday for lack of votes.

title: Political Lobbying on Steel Tariffs
summary: Ten House Members oppose this exclusion request, but 14 favor it.. How's this for swampy? A company seeks an exclusion from President Trump's 25% steel tariffs. While it is awaiting the Commerce Department's judgment, concerned U.S. Representatives get into a tug of war, trying to pull political strings in both directions.

title: Putin's Foreign Assassination Playbook
summary: Evidence shows the FSB organized a daytime killing in Berlin.. When rogue states like Russia wreak havoc on foreign soil, they often work through proxies and deny responsibility. But occasionally the veil slips, as when evidence emerged this week that Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) planned and carried out an assassination in Germany last summer.

title: A Tax-Cut Idea for Trump
summary: Creating targeted tax-free investment accounts may be the most effective way to reduce wealth inequality.. The White House is expected to announce details of its tax cuts for the Trump second term. One idea on the table is to create tax-free investment accounts for lower- and middle-income families.

title: Bernie's Millions Beat Mike's Billions
summary: Small donors signal and cement a loyal following, which a candidate can't buy with money alone.. Serious presidential candidates don't quit running because they lose a few primaries. They quit because they run out of money.

title: Trump Takes a Stand for the Mentally Ill
summary: His budget proposes to end a 55-year ban on Medicaid funding for institutional care.. Hundreds of thousands of Americans with serious mental illness sleep in jails, shelters and prisons on any given night. Fewer than 40,000 are in state psychiatric hospitals. This is largely due to a federal policy, the Institutions for Mental Disease Exclusion, which created a financial incentive for states to kick the mentally ill out of hospitals. The White House's new budget proposes easing the exclusion. It's the most important thing federal government could do to improve care for the seriously mentally ill.

title: Trump Outswamps the 5G Swamp
summary: A judge's ruling clears the way for Sprint and T-Mobile after years of rigmarole.. Donald Trump's administration likes living dangerously on 5G. It pulled an unlikely victory out of its hat when a judge approved the wireless merger of Sprint and T-Mobile that's been in the works for nearly a decade. The judge gave the OK, he said, because his crystal ball (his words) was just as good or bad as those of the plaintiffs and defendants.

title: Bloomberg Says He Plans to Sell Company if Elected President
summary: Billionaire candidate would put financial-data and media company in blind trust and eventually sell. Michael Bloomberg will sell Bloomberg LP, the multibillion-dollar financial-data and media company he co-founded nearly 40 years ago, if he is elected president, his campaign said Tuesday.

title: 'A Fistful of Shells' Review: Buyers, Sellers and Rulers
summary: Europeans arrived in West Africa as supplicants to powerful indigenous rulers with economies rich in food, metals, cloth-and slaves.. Contrasting images of the upstart slaving-kingdom of Dahomey reached Enlightenment Europe. In an engraving of the 1780s, the African king leans elegantly on a musket-the source of his army's might. His nose is fine-bridged and olive-tinted, under gleaming European millinery. In a rival image of a few years later, a bloated paramount lolls drunkenly among half-naked women, receiving ludicrous salutations from groveling subjects. The realm puzzled visiting Westerners, who reported dining on haute cuisine with silver-handled forks, after approaching over a path made of the skulls of human-sacrifice victims.

title: A Bid to Revise the New York Times's Bad History
summary: The '1776 Project' will counter the claim that America was founded to preserve 'slavocracy.'. "I think the important point to make about slavery is that it had existed for thousands of years without substantial criticism," said the historian Gordon Wood in an interview last year. "But it's the American Revolution that makes it a problem for the world. And the first real anti-slave movement takes place in North America. So this is what's missed by these essays in the 1619 Project."

title: Why the Young Back Bernie Sanders
summary: They grew up in a vastly different America and many didn't learn history.. In one respect, at least, the Democratic nominating contest is running true to form: Sen. Bernie Sanders is getting the lion's share of young adults' votes. In New Hampshire, for example, voters under 30 represented 15% of the total but 28% of Mr. Sanders's support. Voters 65 and older were 25% of the total but only 13% of the Sanders coalition.

title: State Department Names Five Chinese Media Outlets as Foreign Missions in U.S.
summary: Outlets are 'substantially owned and effectively controlled' by the Chinese government, a State Department official said. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is heightening scrutiny of China's large state-owned media outlets in the U.S., designating them as foreign missions, in a further effort to rein in Chinese government activity.

title: Compared With Boeing, Even Airbus's Year Looks Smooth
summary: The European plane maker has grappled with many problems in 2019, but investors were understandably fixated on Boeing's 737 MAX crisis. The old Oscar Wilde dictum is that "there is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about." Unless, of course, you are competing in a duopoly with Boeing .
